Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <original_username> could it just be people renting hashrate on AWS spot for example? They pile on a load of instances when they are available, and then when the spot capacity is required elsewhere, their instances are terminated by Amazon. Or other off peak usage etc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> there is nothing wrong with non-constant hashrate

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> and spot prices could be the reason, off hour computer networks, etc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> I know I am in that category with random hours in the cloud.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> It looks good to me.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> I had it so I figured I would put it out there as a visual reference.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> I think if you had 10-20% of the total hashrate you could expect certain reward qty, but at .5% it is just too small to be predictable in any way over a few weeks.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <cryptopat> Can I ask people what an optimum number of threads to mine with is ?  Should it have anything to do with how  many cores a CPU has ?  I have been using values of 24, 100, 300, and most recently 600 ðŸ˜„

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> I look at my CPU usage. I increase the # of threads until it is just under 100%. Going over seem to sometimes drop the hashrate. This is usually the # of cores or just a little over the # of cores.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <wistar> @bigtom : That is what I have been doing, too.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <cryptopat> @bigtom  cheers for the advice .....

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <cryptopat> The exchange listing is promising, looks like it was going for about 5 bucks a coin ... yippee .... now just need the coins to mature ðŸ˜„

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <MasonGreene> For everyone having bad luck with staking I'm sorry to hear about it. I think it just is bad luck though, I have been staking with 374 coins on my laptop and have gotten 3840 time locked ones.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> yes, the way it works is that for each person who is having worse luck than expected, there is someone having better luck than expected. however people having worse luck are 100x more likely to post about it. If you are getting any blocks at all, then you are all setup. Even if you are not getting any blocks if it prints the 256 million hashes, you are mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> @jl777c Any chance that something done in the retargeting affected some nodes or something?   been averaging 4-6 blocks per day then since the retarget block... nothing in the last 28 hours or so.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Hashing with about 1.4 Gh/s

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Probably a case of Post hoc ergo propter hoc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @jimboscott i'm not mining with enough to tell myself. i get a block every few days right now... i will ask Alex if any stats that we are running look off. last I heard, we were seeing things pretty close to target, so not more or less significantly than expected.
I have been getting the expected amount on my staking returns from the ones I bought OTC a while back

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Quick question that still seems to float around.... speaking strictly of MINERS - how many blocks per day go to miners?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> about 720, but the difficulty includes all blocks

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> so, the right calc is assuming 1440

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> So, if I take my hashrate, divide it by the net hash, then multiply x 720 - that is my expected mining rewards...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> 1440

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> OK.  That seemed to be more in line with my real world results but a couple of people were telling me to use 720 and not 1440.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> pos calculations should be 1/2'ed, but not PoW

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> OK.  Appreciate the help and your being here late...  interesting project and I do not say that about many

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> I should get about 3.5 per day.  My 4-6 has been good luck and now I am paying the piper.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> PoS has been running at around 52% since the switch, not sure if that is due to the long history at 46% being adjusted for

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> last I had checked, it was converging towards 50%, but I did see that it overcompensated at first. should be running normally by now.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Looks like 1695 blocks since I found anything from mining based upon confirmations on my youngest find.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> so, a little over a day

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> That's right.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> But my first calendar day with a goose egg.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i've seen rates in the 700's since yesterday, as well as lower than now. seems unlucky, but not many std devs, i would think

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Hey... I found 10 on the last day of 384 blocks with a smaller percent of nethash.   Like I said - time to pay the piper now.  Thanks for the advice. Gotta saw some logs now.

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> goodnight

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> In case anyone missed it, head over to #active-bounties . We've got some new bounties going, and a lot of it is stuff anyone can do.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> I am not seeing the benefit of sending people to discord from the media. Just does not seem appropriate.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> we were thinking that it would be better to have a few points and refer people to the original text for details, rather than if there was an error made in writing about it or to know about updates. earning the bounties is through submitting here, as we have to have a reasonable way to manage giving out so much

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> what do you think would cover those things and be better?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> cut and paste, plus a link could work as well, but with no link, it seems no one will be able to earn a bounty.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> The issue is the original text is in discord. Many people in their daily lives walk around never knowing about discord. They know and understand the web and PDFs. I understand the need to attract more people in the crypto community that use discord, but I guess ai understood your request to be a general public awareness. Many coins fail or struggle because they never branch out of the crypto community.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> Everyone has heard of BTC. Going that route sounds like a good path.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i agree with what you're saying, so do you believe that posting the original text more broadly with links covers things?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> Maybe housing the original text on versuscoin.io or some other publicly accessible location.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> ok, but no need to wait for that to cut and paste with links. @englal thoughts?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> I would be happy see Verus headlining the nightly news as the new block chain that does not have a the 51% problems BTC has. How can we help you get there from here?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> Given the recent security issues with BTC and the general decline in value, I think it would be good to leverage some of that media momentum.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> The CV of everyone in the core team is is also impressive. Not a bunch of kids in a bungalow hoping their coin works with a hacked together block chain. .

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> BTW. Wikipedia is on a rampage when it comes to crypto. They are basically not taking any articles about new coins until they are bigger or in the media. They pulled my article on VRSC.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> I'm working on an article about security and will do a video on security soon, but I agree with you and other perspectives. If you have ideas for other places, that would be great, and I'm hoping that the information starts flowing from the community, so that I can put as much focus as possible on getting PBaaS up ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> too bad about Wikipedia, but maybe the VerusHash hash function and the fact that it is fully open source and the fastest hash algorithm in the world on CPUs could make somewhere on Wikipedia. We also have our own PoS and PoW/PoS hybrid. Without being about the coin/project itself, those things seem like they'd be interesting to a lot of people as well, which would likely lead them to the project.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> The verus blockchain is bigger than VRSC. That is for sure, do you have anyone doing professional press releases?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> If we did, it would be from our group, bounties, or others involved, so though some of us have done that work before, we don't have anyone specifically focused on PR. we do have someone who will be writing bi-weekly newsletter and is coordinating bloggers and video, and we'd certainly welcome that kind of help.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> Ok.

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: before I completely drive my head through a wall, does verus agama actually use the Komodo komodod or just download the Komodo/supernet.org binaries in order to get nanomsg and others?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> It uses its own komodod, which should support the same coins as well as Verus. There were some breaking changes in Electrum recently which made SPV not work for coins on our version of Agama, and we are testing the changes to reenable that

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: OK, because I'm trying to make it work on deb 8.7 and running into issue after issue in trying to build from git

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: I guess my best bet is probably to static the daemon and use that

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content:
Well, that turned out to be easier than I thought.
In order to build on "older" systems, one need only remove `-Wint-conversion` from the make file and it builds as expected ðŸ˜ƒ
